Frank Sherwin was born in Derby and studied at the Derby School of Art and then in Chelsea, London at the Heatherleys School of Fine Art.
He specialised in watercolours, but is remembered for the railway posters which promoted travel to holiday destinations around Britain and were very much part of the railways in the days of steam. He did posters for GWR, LMS, LNER & British Rail.
During the war he was an advisor to the War Office on the camouflage of air fields. It is also said that some of his paintings were used in wartime posters.
For the last forty six years of his life he lived in the High Street, in Cookham Village in Berkshire. There was an exhibition of his work at the Cookham Festival in 2007.  Cookham is also the village of Sir Stanley Spencer, one of England's most renowned artists.
Frank died in 1986 at Slough.

response: Frank Sherwin (1905–1981) was an Irish independent politician who sat for eight years as Teachta Dála (TD) for Dublin North-Central, from 1957 to 1965.

Sherwin was born in Upper Dorset Street in inner-city Dublin in 1905, son of a carter. At the age of ten he witnessed intense fighting on North King Street near his home during the Easter Rising of 1916. He left school at 14, and became an apprentice harness-maker.Frank Sherwin, Independent and Unrepentant, pp. 5–11.

He was captured after an attack on Wellington Barracks in November 1922, and badly beaten in custody. As a result, he eventually suffered a stroke and lost the use of his right arm. He was interned at the Curragh Camp and released in 1924.Frank Sherwin, Independent and Unrepentant, pp. 16–28.

Sherwin joined Fianna Fáil in 1926, and in 1939 was elected to the party's Ard Comhairle (National Executive). During World War II he joined the Irish Army as a reserve with other Fianna veterans. He fell out with Fianna Fáil in 1943 after the party refused to nominate him as a candidate for a general election. After a brief flirtation with Clann na Poblachta, he first ran as an independent in 1945.Frank Sherwin, Independent and Unrepentant, pp. 34–57.

He remained a republican sympathiser throughout his life and wrote in his memoirs in the 1970s that "The Provisional IRA can not be expected to disappear as if they had never fought and suffered". On the Northern Ireland question he wrote, "the solution to the northern problem is for the British Army to get out... The Orangemen would not last a week against the northern nationalists supported by southern government. If the Orangemen did fight it would be a good thing in the long run as it would clear the northern area of foreign bigots".Frank Sherwin, Independent and Unrepentant, pp. 204–205.
Dublin's Frank Sherwin Bridge, opened in 1982, is named in his honour.
*Frank Sherwin (artist), remembered for the railway posters which promoted travel to holiday destinations around Britain
*Frank Sherwin Bridge, road bridge spanning the River Liffey in Dublin, Ireland
